title: Kentucky Biscuits Recipe
description: This is a great recipe, different than the usual biscuit. Serve piping hot with butter, jam, or honey.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Bread Quick Bread Recipes Biscuits Kentucky Biscuits 4.6 (1,094) 860 Reviews 247 Photos This is a great recipe, different than the usual biscuit. Serve piping hot with butter, jam, or honey. Submitted by COOKIN4MY3BOYS Updated on July 14, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 247 247 247 247 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 15 mins Total Time: 30 mins Servings: 12 Yield: 12 biscuits Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 12 servings 2 cups all-purpose flour 2 ½ teaspoons baking powder ½ teaspoon baking soda 1 dash salt 1 tablespoon white sugar ½ cup butter ¾ cup buttermilk Directions Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). In a bowl, mix the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and sugar. Cut in 1/2 cup butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Mix in the buttermilk. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead 2 minutes. Transfer to an ungreased baking sheet, roll into a 6x6 inch square, and cut into 12 even sections. Do not separate. Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until a knife inserted in the center of the square comes out clean. Separate into biscuits, and serve hot. I Made It Print 2,244 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 154 Calories 8g Fat 18g Carbs 3g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 12 Calories 154 % Daily Value * Total Fat 8g 10% Saturated Fat 5g 25% Cholesterol 21mg 7% Sodium 231mg 10% Total Carbohydrate 18g 7% Dietary Fiber 1g 2% Total Sugars 2g Protein 3g 5% Vitamin C 0mg 0% Calcium 65mg 5% Iron 1mg 6% Potassium 48mg 1% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Kentucky Biscuits 01 of 247 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 247 Photo by  TraciAnn And BB 07/31/2024 I followed recipe to a T, except I only fold dough, and never knead. Very good biscuit recipe, and very easy to make. Like others have said, the dough is very sticky but worth the effort. Biscuits come out nice, moist and so tasty! Thanks for sharing this recipe and method for cutting and baking. I will be sure to use this one again. 03 of 247 Photo by  Dynamar 09/10/2023 The best biscuit recipe I’ve found. I turn out the dough on a lightly floured board right before it comes together, then fold over a few times with a dough scraper. I do this rather than kneading as the recipe says for a more tender biscuit. Gently roll to your desired thickness as soon as all the pieces stick together. We like our biscuits thick, so the recipe only yields 6-8 pieces… just enough for a couple meals. To take these to the next level… add a teaspoon of fresh thyme leaves and the zest of one lemon. Divine with sausage gravy. 04 of 247 Photo by  Julia Chou 05/21/2022 I tried to make the Biscuits this early morning according to your recipe.Thanks for sharing. 05 of 247 Photo by  Emily Holding 09/09/2021 Oh I’ve never made biscuits before. I didn’t exactly get them into a square shape but were absolutely delicious. I didn’t change anything. Once they were ready I tried one with just butter and then I had more with butter and jam almost like a scone thank you so much. Tomorrow we’re having these with fried chicken. 06 of 247 Photo by  Monica R 09/09/2021 I like this recipe, although I substituted self rising flour and just left out the baking soda and salt, nice fluffy biscuits. Family enjoyed 07 of 247 Photo by  mom 09/03/2021 Made these this morning because I had to use up some buttermilk and was pleasantly surprised how flakey they where. Best biscuits I’ve ever made, these will definitely be a staple in our house. 08 of 247 Photo by  Vanessa Bunn 08/02/2021 09 of 247 Photo by  Solomon03 07/29/2021 10 of 247 Photo by  Magda 07/05/2021 My family and friends love these! I used cake flour instead of AP, make sure I keep the butter cold, do not over mix (I like to make sure I can see small pieces of butter mixed in the dough. Make sure you fold several times- helps w layering! Serve fresh out of the oven. We love the w orange marmalade. Also sometimes I brush them w honey butter. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love 7Up Buttermilk Biscuits Mayonnaise Biscuits 576 Ratings South Georgia Biscuits 65 Ratings Cathead Biscuits 59 Ratings Crissi's Sweet Potato Biscuits 4 Ratings Chef John's Sweet Potato Biscuits 14 Ratings Quick Cranberry Pumpkin Muffins 48 Ratings Granny's Banana Bread 167 Ratings Sweet Potato Biscuits 117 Ratings Greg's Southern Biscuits 188 Ratings Corn Cornbread 17 Ratings Low-Calorie Buttermilk Biscuits Pepperoni Rolls 177 Ratings Chef John's Butter Puff Biscuit Dough 37 Ratings Kentucky Banana Pudding 171 Ratings Whole Wheat Sourdough Biscuits 1 Rating Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: COOKIN4MY3BOYS
instructions: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).;In a bowl, mix the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and sugar. Cut in 1/2 cup butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Mix in the buttermilk. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead 2 minutes. Transfer to an ungreased baking sheet, roll into a 6x6 inch square, and cut into 12 even sections. Do not separate.;Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until a knife inserted in the center of the square comes out clean. Separate into biscuits, and serve hot.
